summary: 10/2005: Suspected members of Al-Qa`ida in Iraq, also known as Tawhid al-Jihad, executed a contractor, Mohammed Mahmoud Alwan, on a video posted to an Islamic website on 10/18/2005. The perpetrators killed Alwan for working with pro-Western forces in Iraq.
target1: An Iraqi national working with western froces
motive: Alwan was killed for working with westerners in Iraq.
addnotes: The video was released on 10/18/2005, but the date of the execution was unknown. Tawhid al-Jihad is also known as Abu Mus'ab al-Zarqawi's Al-Qa`ida in Iraq.

summary: 11/10/2005: A suicide bomber targeted the Qadduri restaurant frequented by Iraqi policemen, in central Baghdad, Iraq killing 34 people and injuring 25 others. Al-Qa`ida in Iraq claimed responsibility for the attack via a statement posted on a website.
target2: Qadduri restaurant patrons
target3: The Qadduri restaurant in central Baghdad
motive: The internet statement indicated that the attack was revenge on behalf of the Sunni population of Qaim, Iraq.  The statement also indicated that the restaurant was targeted because many of its customers were "infidels" as well as Iraqi policemen.
weapdetail: The perpetrator carried the bomb in a satchel and also wore an explosives belt.
propcomment: A restaurant sustained damage in the attack.

summary: 12/06/2005: Two police officers blew themselves up at Baghdad’s police academy building, killing at least 36 fellow officers and wounding at least 72 more. Al-Qa`ida in Iraq claimed responsibility for the incident. This incident was similar to other attacks on U.S. Army and Iraqi police forces during this period before parliamentary elections and during Saddam Hussein’s trial.
weapdetail: The two perpetrators were said to have suicide/explosive vests.
addnotes: This was part of several related incidents: the first source states that there were several incidents where Iraqi security personnel were killed, an Iraqi civilian was killed by a makeshift bomb near a restaurant (cf. 200512060005), and there was an American contractor, Ronald Schulz, kidnapped that appeared to be on this date, but further evidence showed that it was in November. Concerning this incident, the news sources seem to think it was two policewomen who carried out the attack, but Al Qaida's claim of responsibility mentions two men. A U.S. contractor was hurt in the attack.
scite1: "Iraq suicide bombing kills 36 police in election run-up,” Agence France Presse, December 6, 2005.
scite2: “Al-Qaeda claims Baghdad police attack,” Agence France Presse, December 6, 2005
scite3: Sameer N. Yacoub, “Suicide bombers hit Baghdad police academy; American reported kidnapped,” The Associated Press, December 6, 2005.

summary: 12/29/2005: Al-Qa`ida in Iraq members kidnapped six Sudanese nationals, including a diplomat, in Baghdad, Iraq. All of the hostages were released two days later after the Sudanese government agreed to close down their Embassy in Iraq per the request of the perpetrators.
motive: To get the Sudanese government officials out of Iraq.
weapdetail: There was no mention of weapons in the source.
ransomnote: Al-Qa`ida demanded that Sudan withdraw its Embassy in Iraq.  They complied and the hostages were set free.
addnotes: Six Sudanese hostages were said kidnapped, but Al-Qaida only mentioned 5 in their internet claim of responsibility and also it was said that only 5 were released. It is unknown what happened to the six victim. Al-Qa`ida demanded that Sudan shut down their Iraqi Embassy in 48 hours and they complied.
scite1: “AFP: Sudanese Hostages in Iraq Released,” Agence France Presse, December 31, 2005.
